awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a CytoViva enhanced microscope with hyperspectral imaging capability for multidisciplinary research and education in nanotechnology
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanoscience and technology are playing an increasing role in fundamental research related to the engineering (e.g., mechanical, biomedical) and scientific (e.g., chemistry, biology) disciplines. To be able to observe and control phenomena at nanoscale, researchers need to be equipped with appropriate tools. This award will facilitate the acquisition of a specialized microscope used to visualize samples at very small dimensions. Students and faculty at Marshall University will use this microscope to gain fundamental knowledge in a range of important research projects. These include investigating calcium deposit in blood vessels, detecting toxic nanoparticles in human cells, water treatment to remove contamination, and in pharmaceutical manufacturing. This cutting-edge instrument will significantly advance the academic careers and research output of at least five faculty members. More than 100 mostly underrepresented students will be trained, under faculty mentorship, in modern engineering and scientific disciplines both during lectures, laboratory modules, and demonstrations. The incorporation of nanoscience and technology in the undergraduate and graduate curriculum will help training the future workforce, especially in the growing biotechnology arena in West Virginia.

This award enables Marshall University to purchase a CytoViva enhanced, high signal-to-noise darkfield optical microscope with an integrated hyperspectral imaging system. This instrument will be used to address fundamental knowledge gaps in highly multidisciplinary nanoscience and nanotechnology research projects at the university. The microscope produces a very high signal-to-noise ratio, enabling scatter detection of nanoscale materials at up to ten times greater than standard darkfield optics. The technology can image label-free nanoparticles and requires no sample preparation. Label-free nanoscale materials can then be spectrally identified based on their unique spectral properties within their target environment. The microscope will enable Marshall faculty in biomedical and mechanical science and engineering to accelerate their research contributions and improve teaching through innovative laboratory demonstrations and the integration of research and pedagogy. Researchers will use the instrument’s capability to examine phenomena such as cell differentiation, understanding the environmental exposure to silver nanoparticles, label-free quantitation of short nucleic acids using Surface immobilized plasmonic sensors for RNA, nanoparticle aggregation in water treatment, and Brownian motion and aggregation of nanofluids.

This project is jointly funded by the Major Research Instrumentation Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

This project, supported by the National Science Foundation, aimed to address critical knowledge gaps in nanoscience and nanotechnology with a focus on biomedical applications. The acquisition and utilization of the CytoViva hyperspectral imaging system have driven innovative research, student training, and outreach activities that significantly contribute to both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the work.

Intellectual Merit

The CytoViva system has been instrumental in advancing our understanding of nanoparticle interactions in biological and environmental systems. Highlights include:

1. Engineering Nanoparticles for Vascular Health:
Researchers developed reconstituted high-density lipoprotein (rHDL) nanoparticles to study their uptake by macrophages and their potential to treat vascular calcification. Key findings demonstrated that nanoparticle size significantly influences cellular uptake, with larger nanoparticles achieving higher internalization rates. This insight provides a foundation for designing targeted nanoparticle-based delivery systems for treating inflammatory diseases such as atherosclerosis.

2. Exploring Nano-Bio Interactions in the Brain:
Advanced imaging techniques revealed the localization of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) within cells. Researchers identified the molecular relationships between individual structural proteins and nanoparticles in neural cells exposed to AgNPs. These findings enhance our understanding of the safety and potential risks of nanoparticles in consumer products and medical applications.

3. Advancing Plasmonic Sensors for DNA Detection:
A shift from fluorescence-based to plasmonic-based sensors enabled the development of triangular gold nanoparticles (TGN) for detecting DNA binding events. This research paves the way for creating highly sensitive, reproducible biosensors, with applications in diagnostics and molecular biology.

4. Insights into Nanoparticle Behavior in Microchannels:
The project provided critical insights into nanoparticle behavior, particularly agglomeration patterns within microchannels. Using Cytoviva imaging, researchers visualized how nanoparticle clustering affects heat transfer efficiency in nanofluids. These findings contribute to the design of more efficient nanofluid-based cooling systems, with applications in micro-cooling devices and other thermal management systems.

5. Advancing Water Treatment Technologies:
The Cytoviva system was used to analyze nanosized particles in flocculation processes, providing novel insights into particle dynamics and interactions. These findings support the optimization of water treatment techniques and enhance sustainability. This work demonstrates the potential of nanotechnology for addressing critical environmental challenges.

Broader Impacts

The project has had a profound impact on education, training, and public understanding of nanotechnology:

1. Student Training and Outreach:

  • Over 30 undergraduate and graduate students have been trained in using the CytoViva system, equipping them with skills to conduct cutting-edge research. NSF REU participants and high school students engaged in nanoparticle development projects, fostering early interest in STEM fields.
  • In-class demonstrations and hands-on lab activities in courses like BME306 (Tissue Engineering) and ME325 (Thermal/Fluid Lab) have captivated students and provided valuable experiential learning opportunities.

2. Community Engagement:

  • Outreach activities, such as training sessions and capstone projects, have encouraged students across disciplines to engage with nanotechnology research. These efforts have broadened participation in STEM and inspired future researchers.

3. Contributions to Public Health, Sustainability, and Safety:

  • By characterizing the interactions of nanoparticles with biological systems, the project has provided insights into their safety and efficacy in health-related products.
  • Research into flocculation processes and nanoparticle behavior supports the development of more efficient and sustainable water treatment methods. These findings empower researchers, policymakers, and the public to make informed decisions regarding nanomaterial applications.

Key Outcomes

Scientific Discoveries:

  • Identification of size-dependent uptake of rHDL nanoparticles by macrophages, advancing targeted drug delivery for vascular diseases.
  • Demonstration of the persistence of silver nanoparticles in brain tissues, highlighting potential health risks.
  • Development of reproducible triangular gold nanoparticles for sensitive DNA detection.
  • Visualization of nanoparticle agglomeration in microchannels, contributing to the design of improved thermal management systems.
  • Novel insights into nanoparticle behavior in flocculation processes, optimizing water treatment techniques.

Publications and Presentations:

  • Results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journals, national conferences, and student-led poster sessions, contributing to the broader scientific community.

Infrastructure Development:

  • Standard operating procedures for the CytoViva system have been established, ensuring its effective use in future research and collaboration.

Looking Forward

This NSF-supported research continues to push the boundaries of nanotechnology and its applications in medicine, biology, and environmental sustainability. The findings not only address critical knowledge gaps but also inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers to explore the potential of nanomaterials for solving global challenges.
